div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Boston Evening, 1906
div1.p:
All readers interested in detective
stories, of the identification, arrest,
trial, sentence and execution of
heinous criminals, miscreated, dia-
bolic and hell-born in the very grain,
will find a rare treat in the recently
published biography of Dr. Walter
Reed, surgeon and ranking major in
the United States army. At the same
time they will feel their moral enthu-
siasm and zest in hero worship raised
to the highest pitch--a happy result
not always experienced through over-
addiction to the reading of detective
stories, where too often the detective
himself strikes one as not a whit the
superior in the practice of the cardi-
nal virtues to the malefactor he hunts
down.

The criminal in this now world-
famous case was no less and no greater
a personage than the familiarly-
known mosquito. This seems a pretty
small class for a scentifically-edu-
cated United States officer to pit his
intellect against. Here was no Jona-
than Wild or Captain Kidd or even
Dick Turpin to test one's mettle of
valor. But, alas! as great Edmund
Burke said 200 years ago, “The age
of chivalry is gone; that of sophis-
ters, economists and calculators has
succeeded.”

Lower yet even than to Burke's
sophisters, economists and calcula-
tors, in the room of the Chevalier
Bayards and Sir Philip Sidneys of
yore have we of today fallen--into the
realm, indeed, of the gnats, pismires
and mosquitos--nay, below the “low-
est deep a lower deep still threat-
ening to devour us opens wide.” It is
into the realm of the most insignifi-
cant and invisible microbes and bac-
teria.

Here, then, is to be sought the
veritable haunts of the primeval
dragons, belching forth smoke and
pestilence over whole lands, which
the St. Georges of old rode out, spear
in hand, to slay and deliver the trem-
bling peoples from--yes, here crouch
the dragons, invincible as the “arrow
that flieth by day and the pestilence
that walketh in darkness,” which the
chivalrous knight of today, “without
fear and without reproach,” is sum-
moned to prick forth to meet.

Alas! small game to hunt, these
mosquito and pismire dragons! is the
first impression on the imagination--
more contemptible even, in the way
of sport, than hunting guinea pigs in-
stead of wild boars and tigers.

Turn, however, to the pages of his-
tory and read the most authentic and
carefully tabulated statistics that
have come down to posterity of the
havoc wrought by the fellest, scaly
and pestilence-breathing dragon St.
George ever slew! It will be found
that the dragon could never hold a
candle to the mosquito.

True, the dragons were many of
them winged creatures, and so, seem-
ingly, participating in an aerial na-
ture. But, like all the winged sau-
rians, they were awkward and cum-
bersome flyers. Besides, their powers
of reproduction were of the most par-
simoniously stingy order--three or
four dragons, perhaps, to the litter.
How, then, would the mosquito,
blithely singing as he flies, and in the
most nonchalant and touch-and-go
way depositing on the scum of every
stagnant pool the embryos of half a
million lineal heirs, smile in his
sleeve at such a lumbering and race-
suiciding monster. After which, and
as though all this were a mere baga-
telle, how would he again rise blithely
on the air, derisively singing, “He that
despiseth little things shall perish lit-
tle by little!”

No one can thoughtfully read this
book, “Walter Reed and Yellow
Fever,” without feeling that a pro-
found and fairly revolutionary effect
has been wrought on his imagination.
The story is most succintly and lu-
minously told by Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
surgical professor in Johns Hopkins
University, who has done his work
in a manner at once thoroughly scien-
tific and thoroughly artistic. Dr.
Kelly knows how to mass his forces.
Under his skilful hands the despised
mosquito rises to the giant propor-
tions of a Goliath of Gath, with a
spear like a weaver's beam, which
the heroic stripling David, under the
alias of Walter Reed, who planked a
stone deep into his forehead, rises
a thousandfold more strongly en-
trenched in our heroic admiration
than even on the occasion of that
first historical encounter in which he
delivered his people from the terror
of the giant Philistine.

In truth, to get a truly adequate
impression of the effect wrought by
this book on the imagination of the
reader, one must vividly recall to
mind the scene in the Arabian Nights,
where the fisherman uncorks the bot-
tle which had been cast ashore. The
fisherman no doubt welcomed it as
a bottle of spirit, gin, rum or brandy.
A bottle of spirit it veritably was, but
of a kind of spirit, or genius, which
King Solomon had condensed into it
and sealed up ages before.

The cork no sooner extracted, but
out began to stream the liberated
genius, a terror and portent darken-
ing the sky like a black thunder cloud
and terrifying the cowering inhabi-
tants beneath. Such the reappear-
ance, on the lurid sky of the imagi-
nation, of the mosquito since Dr.
Walter Reed and his scientific con-
querors have uncorked the mere vial
of restricted intellectual apprehension
in which he had previously been con-
fined by an unscientific public.

From beginning to end the whole
story of the combat instituted between
the yellow fever Goliath mosquito and
the valiant little David, Walter Reed,
is one magnificent piece of intelli-
gence, heroism and humanity. It
seems to usher in a new “age of the
martyrs” ready to die for the faith;
of fresh Latimers and Ridleys. The
man who shows himself willing and
glad to load up his suspected enemy,
the mosquito, with all the yellow
fever germs he can hold and then let
him bite him, so as to make him turn
states evidence against himself, re-
veals the modern type of hero, mar-
tyr or saint. But for soul-stirring
details of this everybody must be
sure to read the book itself!
